Journal.Title: Langmuir : the ACS journal of surfaces and colloids

Article.ArticleTitle: Impact of the Surface and Microstructure on the Lubricative Properties of MoS<sub>2</sub> Aging under Different Environments.

AbstractText: Molybdenum disulfide (MoS<sub>2</sub>) with a hydrophobic property and layered structure possesses an excellent lubricative property and has been widely used as a lubricant in various areas, including satellites, aircraft, and new energy vehicles. Aging is a ubiquitous phenomenon in MoS<sub>2</sub> and plays a key role in its tribological application for shortening its service life. The effect of the surface and microstructure on the lubricative properties of MoS<sub>2</sub> aging under different environments, including deionized water (DI water), ultraviolet/ozone (UV/Ozone), and high-temperature, was investigated. First, the lubrication of MoS<sub>2</sub> transiently degrades because of physical adsorption and recovers after mechanical removal. The lubrication of MoS<sub>2</sub> also degrades slightly when its surface becomes hydrophilic, thereby enhancing the adhesion energy due to atomic oxygen interaction under UV/Ozone exposure. Second, the lubrication of MoS<sub>2</sub> degrades irreversibly because of the formation of stripes with the destroyed structures under accelerated aging. The lubrication of MoS<sub>2</sub> further degrades with the formation of small triangular pits under high-temperature annealing. Finally, the lubrication of MoS<sub>2</sub> deteriorates due to the destroyed structure and complete oxidation. The severe aging of MoS<sub>2</sub> is accompanied with large triangular pits due to anisotropic oxidation etching of MoS<sub>2</sub>. The lubrication failure of MoS<sub>2</sub> was determined on the basis of structural defect formation and surface property degradation induced by the extent of oxygen diffusion. The enhanced out-of-plane deformation due to the reduced out-of-plane stiffness and the increased energy barriers of defects are fundamentally responsible for the lubrication degradation of MoS<sub>2</sub> at the atomic scale. These findings can provide new insights into the atomic-scale mechanism underlying the lubrication failure of MoS<sub>2</sub> and pave the way for the realization of MoS<sub>2</sub>-based lubrication application under various environments.
